title: Ticket #5254: bad permissions on config files cause master to kill itself on reconfi
description:
If /etc/condor/config.d contains a configuration file that is not readable by the condor user, then the master starts up normally, but a reconfig will cause it to exit without a log message or killing its daemons.

Looks like the master is acting as root when it reads the config files on initial startup, but is acting as the condor user when doing a reconfig. This inconsistency can keep admins from discovering the error in their config files in the first place.

The master prints the error message to stderr instead of logging it, and exits without shutting down any of its children. These should probably both be fixed.

The logging is most important to me, though I think that from an admin's point of view, the ideal behavior is that if a reconfig fails due to broken files (or any other reason), that Condor should keep running with the old config. I have no idea how feasible that is with the Condor codebase.
